==Morality and wealth==

Socioeconomic factors can have a significant impact on moral issues. For example, a study conducted in the US in 2008<ref name="barna1">{{cite web |url= http://www.barna.org/barna-update/article/15-familykids/42-new-marriage-and-divorce-statistics-released|title= New Marriage and Divorce Statistics Released |author= Barna Group|date= 31 March 2008 |publisher= Barna Group|accessdate= 19 November 2011}}</ref> measured the correlation between wealth and divorce rates, and found that people with an income above $75.000 and a college education only have 22% divorce rate compared to 39% in the group with income below $20.000 per annum. Further benefits of wealth can be derived from crime statistics indicating that crime rates are inversely correlated with GDP<ref>{{cite web|last=Rushton|first=J. Philippe|title=Cross-National Variation in Violent Crime Rates: Race, r-K Theory, and Income|url=http://www.charlesdarwinresearch.org/Crime.pdf|accessdate=5 May 2012}}</ref> albeit others find a positive correlation.<ref>{{cite news|title=Falling together , The relationship between crime and GDP in America|url=http://www.economist.com/blogs/dailychart/2011/09/us-crime-and-gdp|publisher=The Economist|accessdate=5 May 2012|date=2011-09-26}}</ref> More comprehensive analysis shows that the crime rates increase with inequality of wealth distibution.<ref>{{cite web|last=Parsley|first=J.Travis|title=Basic Examination of the Correlation between Crime Rates and Income Inequality|url=http://rri-tmp.wvu.edu/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/REU2001-19.pdf|accessdate=5 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Lee|first=Yoonseok|title=Income Polarization and Crime: A Generalized Index and Evidence from Panel Data|url=http://www-personal.umich.edu/~yoolee/research/Polarization_LeeShin.pdf|accessdate=5 May 2012}}</ref> Comparing [[List of countries by income equality]] and [[List of countries by intentional homicide rate]] gives a visual indication of the importance of wealth distribution. Because of this correlation, some advocate the [[Redistribution of wealth]], possibly to be achieved via taxation. However, the justification of wealth distribution is a matter of debate between philopsophers, social scientists and politicians <ref>{{cite web|last=Barry|first=Christian|title=Redistribution|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/redistribution/|accessdate=5 May 2012}}</ref> Aritstotle in his [[Nicomachean Ethics]] talks about generosity as a virtue and claims that is better to be wasteful than stingy with regards to dealing with money.
